newsitem.title: USA: Calif. flood areas get $8.6 mln in emergency funds.
newsitem.headline: Calif. flood areas get $8.6 mln in emergency funds.

text.p: Twenty-two counties and five cities in California have received nearly $8.6 million in emergency funds due to storm and flood damage in January, federal officials said Friday.

The so-called "fast track" funds, which were made available by the Federal Emergency Management Agency (FEMA) and California's Office of Emergency Services, will help to cover the immediate costs associated with the flooding, officials said in a statement.

"This is the first step in the infrastructure reimbursement process that helps the state, county and local governments deal with cash flow problems caused by the emergency," said Dorothy Lacey, FEMA's federal coordinating officer.
Lacey said these initial reimbursements would be followed by others as inspections of eligible repair and restoration projects are assembled.
The January floods caused an estimated $200 million in damage to public structures, including $87 million in damages to roads and bridges in 48 counties hit by flooding.
